items.title: Chegg Sues Google Over AI Search Summaries
items.summary:
- Chegg has sued Google, alleging that AI summaries in search results have negatively impacted its traffic and revenue.
- The lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia, accusing Google of unfair competition, monopoly maintenance, and unjust enrichment.
- Chegg seeks compensatory damages, relief, and an injunction against Google's allegedly unlawful practices.

items.title: Even Elon Musk forgets that X isn’t Twitter sometimes
items.summary:
- Elon Musk occasionally refers to X as Twitter, despite the rebranding.
- He recently posted about X adding features with fewer people compared to Twitter.
- Musk's message was in response to comments about government efficiency and federal employee productivity listings.
- This isn't the first instance of Musk using the name Twitter for X, indicating a potential habit.

items.title: Holmes and Balwani’s appeal falls flat as court upholds fraud convictions
items.author: Connie Loizos
items.summary:
- Elizabeth Holmes and Ramesh “Sunny” Balwani's appeals against their fraud convictions were denied by the Northern District Court of California.
- They were convicted in separate trials in 2022 for defrauding investors about Theranos’s blood-testing technology and began serving their sentences in 2023.
- The court upheld a joint restitution order of $452 million and dismissed arguments regarding improper testimony and violation of fair trial rights.

items.title: Apple exec Phil Schiller testifies that he raised concerns over App Store commissions on web-based sales
items.author: Sarah Perez
items.summary:
- Phil Schiller testified he raised concerns about a 27% commission on external purchases.  
- He warned it could create an antagonistic relationship with app developers and raise compliance risks.  
- This commission reduction followed a court ruling that allowed developers to link to alternative payment methods.  
- Apple's default commission is 30%, but it dropped to 27% due to legal pressures.  
- Epic Games' CEO criticized Apple's compliance stating it was insufficient.  
- Schiller worried that Apple would become a collection agency affecting its relationship with developers.  
- Internal discussions revealed a lengthy debate at Apple regarding the commissions and potential impacts.  
- It was ultimately decided to charge a commission on external purchases despite Schiller's objections.  
- Documents indicated Apple considered how to implement external links without losing transactions.  
- New guidelines allow for a week to charge for external purchases after a link is clicked.

items.title: DOGE’s HR email is getting the ‘Bee Movie’ spam treatment
items.author: Amanda Silberling
items.summary:
- Elon Musk conducted a survey on X, asking if federal employees should email their weekly accomplishments to his team.
- Over 70% voted yes, leading to a request from the U.S. Office of Personnel Management for federal employees to list their achievements by Monday.
- Social media users are flooding the DOGE-operated HR email with spam, including the complete script of the 'Bee Movie', a tactic of online resistance against controversial emails.
- This follows a precedent of spamming government forms as a form of protest, including previous instances involving anti-trans forms.
- The OPM's HR email address recently faced scrutiny following a lawsuit regarding privacy violations related to the new email server setup.

items.title: A comprehensive list of 2024 and 2025 tech layoffs
items.summary: - In 2024, over 150,000 jobs were cut across 542 tech companies, according to Layoffs.fyi. - Major companies laying off employees include Tesla, Amazon, Google, and Microsoft. - The layoffs continue into 2025, with tracking to analyze the impact of these job cuts on innovation and employment stability. - Specific January 2025 layoffs include 6,003 employees, while December 2024 saw 2,268 laid off, and significant cuts occurred throughout each month of 2024.

items.title: Anthropic used Pokémon to benchmark its newest AI model
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Anthropic tested its latest AI model, Claude 3.7 Sonnet, using Pokémon Red as a benchmark.
- The model was equipped with memory and function calls to play the game continuously.
- Claude 3.7 successfully battled three Pokémon gym leaders, improving upon the previous Claude 3.0 version.
- The model performed 35,000 actions to reach the last gym leader, Surge.
- The testing method highlights gaming's role in AI benchmarking, similar to previous uses in titles like Street Fighter and Pictionary.

items.title: SpaceX says Starship self-destructed after propellant leaks caused fires and comms blackout
items.author: Sean O’Kane
items.summary:
- SpaceX reported the Starship explosion was due to propellant leaks leading to fires and communication loss.
- The company aims to conduct an eighth test flight soon, pending FAA investigation findings.
- Problems initiated two minutes post-launch, causing engine failures and triggering a destruction sequence.
- The explosion created a visual spectacle over Turks and Caicos and influenced FAA to divert flights.
- SpaceX has made adjustments to the fuel lines and engine systems to prevent future leaks.

items.title: SoundCloud partners with TicketMaster to let artists list events
items.author: Ivan Mehta
items.summary:
- SoundCloud announced a partnership with Ticketmaster to let artists list events on their profiles.
- Artists using SoundCloud's Pro plan can utilize Ticketmaster and Universe for event listings.
- SoundCloud will promote events through a concert discovery widget on its homepage.
- The platform takes a 1% cut from ticket sales made through Ticketmaster links.

items.title: Khosla Ventures seeks $3.5B in fresh capital
items.summary:
- Khosla Ventures aims to raise $3.5 billion across three funds, 17% larger than their previous 2023 total of $3 billion.
- Approximately half of the new funds will be allocated to its ninth core venture fund, with $1.1 billion for a growth fund and $650 million for a seed-stage fund.
- Founded in 2004 by Vinod Khosla, the firm has notable managing directors including Keith Rabois, who has a history with investments in companies like DoorDash and Affirm.

items.title: Google Drive users can now access and search transcripts for videos
items.author: Aisha Malik
items.summary:
- Google Drive has launched a new feature allowing users to view and search transcripts for their videos.
- This feature eliminates the need for third-party transcription services, as transcripts will appear in a sidebar next to the video player.
- Users can access transcripts by opening a video with captions and selecting the “Transcript” option in video settings.
- The feature is rolling out over the coming weeks to all Google Workspace customers and users with personal Google accounts.

items.title: Anthropic launches a new AI model that ‘thinks’ as long as you want
items.author: Maxwell Zeff
items.summary:
- Anthropic introduces Claude 3.7 Sonnet, the first ‘hybrid AI reasoning model’ that offers real-time and thorough answers.
- The model allows users to choose the duration of reasoning time, enhancing user experience by simplifying options.
- Claude 3.7 Sonnet will be available to all users on a premium plan, costing $3 per million input tokens and $15 per million output tokens.
- In tests, Claude 3.7 Sonnet achieved accuracy rates of 62.3% on SWE-Bench and 81.2% on TAU-Bench, outperforming OpenAI models.
- Claude’s new reasoning features are expected to reduce unnecessary rejections by 45% compared to its predecessor, Claude 3.5 Sonnet.
- Alongside this model, Anthropic is also launching Claude Code, a tool for developers to interact with AI directly from their terminal.

items.title: Grok 3 appears to be driving Grok usage to new heights
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Elon Musk’s AI company, xAI, released [Grok 3](https://techcrunch.com/2025/02/17/elon-musks-ai-company-xai-releases-its-latest-flagship-ai-grok-3/), its flagship AI model, last week.
- Grok 3 led to a more than 10x increase in worldwide and U.S. mobile app downloads compared to the previous week, with daily active users in the U.S. soaring over 260%.
- The web app's U.S. daily visits rose from around 189,000 to over 900,000, globally growing from 627,000 to 4.5 million.
- Grok 3’s release coincided with the app expanding into several new markets, possibly aiding its growth.
- Recent controversies included Grok 3 briefly censoring mentions of Donald Trump and Musk, attributed to a rogue employee, and it making problematic statements about them which were quickly patched.

items.title: DeepSeek: Everything you need to know about the AI chatbot app
The SEC will not sue Robinhood over crypto
items.summary:
- Robinhood announced that the SEC has closed its investigation into its crypto unit and will not pursue action.
- This comes after Coinbase also reported that the SEC dropped its lawsuit against them.
- The SEC had investigated multiple crypto exchanges regarding how they handled staking assets, which it viewed as unregistered securities.
- Robinhood chose to limit its involvement in certain crypto assets to avoid triggering SEC scrutiny.
- The crypto industry is now seeking to establish regulations, especially under a more crypto-friendly administration.

items.title: Perplexity teases a web browser called Comet
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- AI-powered search engine Perplexity announces it is building a web browser named Comet.
- A signup list has been launched, but the browser is not yet available.
- Perplexity aims to "reinvent the browser" alongside its search engine innovations.
- The browser will compete in a crowded market with existing browsers like Chrome and upcoming AI-powered options like Dia.
- Perplexity has recently expanded its product portfolio, including a deep research product and an AI assistant for Android.
- Founded in 2022, Perplexity has raised over $500 million and has a valuation of $9 billion, with over 100 million weekly search queries.
- The company faces legal challenges regarding content usage from publishers like News Corp and The New York Times.

items.title: Three years on, Europe looks to Ukraine for the future of defense tech
items.summary:
- Today marks three years since Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, highlighting Ukrainian innovation in defense technology amidst the conflict.
- Ukraine established the BRAVE1 defense tech initiative and hosted tech conferences like IT Arena.
- Ukraine has become a leader in AI-enabled drone technology, attracting Western investment to enhance European defense.
- A report by Lakestar warns that Europe is underprepared for potential threats, citing a reduction in defense spending by 30% since the 1990s.
- In 2024, venture capital investment in European defense technology reached over a billion dollars, with significant investments focused in Germany, the UK, and France.
- New specialized defense funds and startups in Ukraine are emerging, with various innovative solutions being developed for defense and dual-use technology.

items.title: TikTok (with Douyin) becomes first app to reach $6B in annual consumer spending
items.author: Sarah Perez
items.summary:
- In 2024, TikTok and its Chinese counterpart Douyin reached $6 billion in annual in-app purchase revenue, becoming the first non-game app to do so.
- TikTok generated a record $1.9 billion in IAP revenue in Q4 2024, surpassing all other non-game apps except for YouTube and Google One.
- TikTok's IAP revenue represents a significant increase from $4.4 billion in 2023.
- Despite high revenue, TikTok was ranked No. 2 in downloads for Q4 2024, behind Instagram.
- Douyin, tailored for the Chinese audience, offers stricter content controls and emphasizes e-commerce more than TikTok.
- TikTok's popularity illustrates its importance in the creator economy, where users can purchase virtual gifts for creators.

items.title: Australia bans government use of Kaspersky software due to ‘unacceptable security risk’
items.summary:
- Australia bans the use of Kaspersky software by government officials due to security risks.
- Directive issued by the Department of Home Affairs prohibits installation of Kaspersky products by April 1.
- Australia joins the Five Eyes intelligence pact members in restricting Kaspersky, including the U.S., U.K., and Canada.

items.title: Researchers accuse North Korea of $1.4 billion Bybit crypto heist
items.author: Lorenzo Franceschi-Bicchierai
items.summary:
- Hackers stole approximately $1.4 billion in Ethereum from crypto exchange Bybit, marking it as the largest crypto heist ever.
- Blockchain monitoring firms and investigator ZachXBT attribute the hack to North Korea's Lazarus Group.
- Elliptic and TRM Labs confirmed North Korea's involvement based on the analysis of stolen funds' laundering patterns.

items.title: The startup battle begins now: TechCrunch Startup Battlefield 200 applications are open
items.summary:
- Applications for the TechCrunch Startup Battlefield 200 are now open.
- The event will take place from October 27-29 at Moscone West in San Francisco.
- Competitors have the chance to win a $100,000 equity-free prize and gain exposure to investors.
- Last year's competition saw thousands of startups apply, indicating fierce competition ahead.
- Early application is encouraged for better chances of consideration.
- Notable alumni include Trello, Mint, and Discord, with over 1,500 alumni in total.
- Target participants include early-stage startups with an MVP and transformative vision.

items.title: As Meta gets rid of fact-checkers, misinformation is going viral
items.summary:
- Meta is ending its third-party fact-checking programs in the U.S. while reintroducing a bonus program for viral content creators.
- The change may lead to increased misinformation as content moderation is being deprioritized.
- Current policies preventing monetization of false posts are being lifted.
- Meta's fact-checking transition will occur in March 2025, but false claims are already spreading.
- Example of misinformation includes a fake claim about ICE paying $750 for tips on undocumented immigrants.

items.title: Flexport releases onslaught of AI tools in a move inspired by ‘Founder Mode’
items.author: Sean O’Kane
items.summary:
- Flexport is launching a suite of over 20 new AI-powered products, marking the start of semi-annual announcements.
- The new approach is inspired by Airbnb’s product announcement strategy, as advised by Airbnb’s CEO, Brian Chesky.
- Key products include Flexport Intelligence for natural language queries on shipments and Control Tower for real-time visibility in logistics.
- AI tools are designed to enhance customer relations rather than replace staff; Flexport believes it will lead to job growth.
- Petersen emphasizes cautious integration of AI, particularly with voice agents for logistics communication, ensuring high quality in customer interactions.
- The next product release is expected in late summer 2025.

items.title: A single default password exposes access to dozens of apartment buildings
items.author: Zack Whittaker
items.summary:
- A security researcher revealed a default password in Hirsch's door access system exposes numerous buildings in the U.S. and Canada.
- Hirsch claims the vulnerability is by design and has no plans to fix it, leaving many buildings at risk.
- The discovered bug is rated 10/10 on the severity scale, allowing unauthorized access to buildings without notifying anyone.

items.title: Cambium is building an AI that helps turn waste wood into usable lumber
items.author: Ben Christensen, Marisa Repka, Theo Hooker
items.summary:
- Cambium addresses the issue of wasted wood in the timber industry, originating from poor coordination in tree care services.
- The startup connects various supply chain components to facilitate the reuse of wood that would otherwise be discarded.
- Cambium has developed its own products, including furniture-grade lumber and cross-laminated timber, partnering with companies like Room and Board and Steelcase.
- The startup raised $18.5 million to enhance its platform, with a focus on developing AI to streamline business operations for timbre businesses, making digitization easier and more responsive to industry needs.

items.title: Patlytics raises $14M for its patent analytics platform
items.author: Kate Park
items.summary:
- Patlytics has developed an AI-enabled patent analytics platform to streamline patent workflows for corporations, IP professionals, and law firms.
- The startup closed $14 million in Series A funding led by Next47, totaling $21 million raised since its inception.
- Patlytics has experienced a 20x increase in annual recurring revenue (ARR) and 300% month-over-month growth, serving clients in several industries and expanding into international markets.

items.title: Meta AI arrives in the Middle East and Africa with support for Arabic
items.author: Paul Sawers
items.summary:
- Meta AI has expanded to the Middle East and North Africa (MENA), now available in 10 countries including Algeria, Egypt, and Saudi Arabia.
- The AI-enabled chatbot supports Arabic and can be accessed via Instagram, WhatsApp, and Messenger.
- Meta plans to go multimodal in MENA, with new features like 'Imagine Me' for selfies and audio dubbing for Instagram Reels.
- Meta AI is now active in 42 countries and supports 13 languages, with an estimated 700 million users across various platforms.

items.title: Apple commits $500B to US manufacturing, including a new AI server facility in Houston
items.author: Ingrid Lunden
items.summary:
- Apple announces a $500 billion investment in the US over the next four years, focusing on high-end manufacturing, engineering, and education.
- Key projects include a new AI server factory in Houston and doubling the US Advanced Manufacturing Fund to $10 billion.
- Groundbreaking for the AI server facility is set for later this year, with completion expected by 2026, enhancing Apple's AI capabilities in U.S. data centers.

items.title: Yope is sparking GenZ (and VC) interest with an Instagram-like app for private groups
items.summary:
- Yope, a photo-sharing app for private groups, has gained 2.2 million monthly active users and 800,000 daily active users, experiencing 30x growth in six months.
- The app raised $4.65 million in seed funding with a valuation of $50 million, led by Goodwater Capital.
- Yope aims to reach 50 million monthly active users by next year, planning to introduce new features including video sharing and interactive group walls.

items.title: Key Cambridge, UK VC launches $126M fund to stem later stage flight
items.author: Mike Butcher
items.summary:
- Cambridge Innovation Capital (CIC) has launched a new £100 million ($126 million) ‘Opportunity Fund’ focused on later-stage startups in deep tech and life sciences.
- The fund aims to fill the funding gap for growth-stage companies in the UK, which is significant compared to the US.
- Two initial investments have been made in Pragmatic Semiconductor and Riverlane.
- CIC's new fund can invest up to £20 million ($25.2 million) per deal.
- The fund is supported by Aviva Investors and British Patient Capital, aligning with UK government's goals to enhance AI and tech growth in popular university ecosystems.

items.title: The lesson of Larry Ellison’s misadventures in farming
items.summary:
- Larry Ellison's venture into farming through Sensei Farms illustrates that expertise in one field does not guarantee success in another.
- Ellison acquired Lāna‘i Island for $300 million in 2012 and invested over $500 million in the venture, which continues to struggle as of 2025.
- Challenges include technical issues, unsuitable greenhouse designs, and operational mistakes, despite minor successes with local produce.

items.title: Google’s new AI video model Veo 2 will cost 50 cents per second
items.summary:
- Google reveals pricing for Veo 2, its AI video-generating model.  
- Cost is set at 50 cents per second, translating to $30 per minute or $1,800 per hour.  
- Compared to the production cost of 'Avengers: Endgame' at around $32,000 per second.  
- Veo 2 is designed for short clips, typically two minutes or more.  
- OpenAI's Sora model priced at $200 per month for subscribers.

items.title: Hyundai’s new Tesla charging port comes up short
items.summary:
- The 2025 Hyundai Ioniq 5 is equipped with Tesla's North American Charging Standard (NACS) port.
- During a test, the charging cable did not reach from the driver’s side to the rear passenger-side charge port.
- Hyundai drivers may need to use existing CCS charging stations and an adapter as a workaround.
- The Ioniq 5 can charge from 10% to 80% at a CCS charger in about 20 minutes, while it takes up to 30 minutes at an NACS charger.
- Hyundai offers a $400 charging credit or a free ChargePoint home charger with the Ioniq 5 purchase.
- The 2025 model features new trims, with larger battery options providing up to 318 miles of range.

items.title: Palantir CEO’s new book says Silicon Valley has ‘lost its way’
items.author: Alexander Karp, Nicholas Zamiska
items.summary:
- Palantir CEO Alexander Karp's new book critiques Silicon Valley for losing its early alliance with the U.S. government.
- The book argues that Silicon Valley has become focused on consumer products rather than addressing broader societal challenges.
- Karp and Zamiska claim the software industry must improve its relationship with the government to tackle pressing issues.
- Critics have described the book as corporate sales material and an outdated perspective on Silicon Valley's role.

items.title: Electric aircraft founder Kyle Clark threw out the Silicon Valley playbook
items.summary:
- 800 attendees witnessed the maiden flight of Beta Technologies’ electric aircraft, the Alia CX300, on November 13.
- Founder Kyle Clark emphasized the importance of keeping promises to the company's board and achieving milestones.
- Beta is strategically headquartered in Vermont, rejecting the Silicon Valley model and venture capital funding.
- The company has developed two aircraft models: the Alia CX300 eCTOL and Alia A250 eVTOL, focusing on different markets.
- Beta aims for FAA certification for the CX300 by 2026 and has solid customer commitments, including Air New Zealand.
- The startup has developed an electric aviation charging network with plans for expansion.
- Clark’s approach to power systems design prioritizes safety and reliability, differing from competitors like Archer and Joby.

items.title: This mental health chatbot aims to fill the counseling gap at understaffed schools
items.summary:
- Sonar Mental Health developed a chatbot named Sonny to support student mental health.
- Sonny combines human staff and AI to respond to student inquiries via text.
- The chatbot is currently used in over 4,500 middle and high schools across nine districts.
- There is a significant shortage of school counselors, with 17% of high schools lacking any counselors at all.

items.title: Grok 3 appears to have briefly censored unflattering mentions of Trump and Musk
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Grok 3, launched by Elon Musk's xAI, was designed to be a 'maximally truth-seeking AI'.
- Users reported that Grok 3 censored mentions of Donald Trump and Elon Musk when asked about misinformation spreaders.
- The issue was repaired after initial discovery, but raised concerns about the model's political bias and censorship capabilities.
- Grok 3's past versions were noted for providing politically lean responses, particularly leaning left on issues like transgender rights.
- Musk has pledged to make Grok politically neutral, in light of criticism regarding perceived left-leaning biases in AI models.

items.title: Did xAI lie about Grok 3’s benchmarks?
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- An OpenAI employee accused xAI of publishing misleading benchmark results for Grok 3.
- xAI claims Grok 3 outperformed OpenAI’s o3-mini-high on AIME 2025, though some scores were omitted.
- The metric 'cons@64' was not included in xAI’s graph, which could alter perceived performance.
- AI researcher Nathan Lambert highlights the importance of considering computational and monetary costs behind score achievements.

items.title: US AI Safety Institute could face big cuts
items.summary:
- The National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) plans to cut up to 500 staff positions, affecting the US AI Safety Institute (AISI).
- Reports suggest that layoffs targeting probationary employees have already commenced, with some receiving verbal notices.
- The AISI, established under President Biden's executive order on AI safety, faces uncertainty following the repeal of that order by President Trump on his return to office.

items.title: How I Podcast: Summer Album / Winter Album’s Jody Avirgan
items.author: Brian Heater
items.summary:
- Jody Avirgan co-hosts the podcast “Summer Album / Winter Album” with Craig Finn of The Hold Steady.
- The podcast categorizes classic records into 'summer' or 'winter' albums.
- Avirgan's home studio setup includes an Electro-Voice RE27N/D mic and FocusRite Scarlett 2i2 interface.
- For portability, he uses an AT2020-USB+ mic for on-the-go recording.
- He enjoys using Descript for audio and video editing, and primarily records video with his MacBook camera.

items.title: The pain of discontinued items, and the thrill of finding them online
items.summary:
- Article discusses the emotional impact of discontinued items on consumers.
- A New York Times piece explores online spaces where shoppers find and support each other regarding these items.
- Highlights a particular case of a Filson laptop bag that is sought after by enthusiasts.
- Mentions the website Discontinued Beauty, which offers hard-to-find beauty products.
- Includes a quote from a creative director about using discontinued items regardless of their storage conditions.

items.title: The fallout from HP’s Humane acquisition
items.author: Cody Corrall
items.summary:
- HP acquired Humane's assets for $116 million, significantly less than the $240 million raised by the startup.
- Humane will discontinue sales of its $499 AI Pins, with full functionality ceasing after February 28.
- Job offers from HP included significant pay increases for some Humane employees, while others were laid off.
- Apple has also revealed the iPhone SE refresh, featuring the new A18 processor and new connectivity options.

items.title: Trump Administration Reportedly Shutting Down Federal EV Chargers Nationwide
items.summary:
- The General Services Administration (GSA) plans to shut down its network of federal electric vehicle (EV) chargers.
- The GSA operates hundreds of EV chargers with around 8,000 plugs for government and federal employee vehicles.
- Federal workers will receive guidance next week on shutting down these chargers, with some regional offices already instructed to take them offline.
- The decision is part of a broader trend under President Trump's administration, which is cutting support for renewable energy and related programs.

items.title: Explore the online world of Apple TV’s ‘Severance’
items.author: Sarah Perez
items.summary:
- Apple is expanding the online presence of its series [“Severance”](https://tv.apple.com/us/show/severance/umc.cmc.1srk2goyh2q2zdxcx605w8vtx) through podcasts, e-books, and more.
- The series has become the most popular show on Apple TV+ and has gained acclaim for its storytelling and relevant societal themes.
- Companion content includes the [Severance Podcast](https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/the-severance-podcast-with-ben-stiller-adam-scott/id1788381175) and various e-books that enhance character lore and theme exploration.
- The creators have committed to a clear narrative direction, unlike previous mystery box shows like “Lost.”
- Season 2 premiered on January 17, 2025, and will run for 10 episodes, concluding on March 21, 2025.

items.title: Meta, X approved ads containing violent anti-Muslim, antisemitic hate speech ahead of German election, study finds
items.summary:
- Meta and X approved ads containing violent anti-Muslim and antisemitic hate speech before Germany's federal elections.
- Eko's research found that most test ads were approved quickly, despite containing hateful messaging targeting minorities.
- X approved all of 10 submitted hate speech ads while Meta approved five, indicating flaws in their content moderation systems.
- The findings suggest revenue generation from distributing violent hate speech, raising concerns about compliance with the EU's Digital Services Act.

items.title: Court filings show Meta staffers discussed using copyrighted content for AI training
items.summary:
- Meta employees debated the use of copyrighted works for AI training through questionable means, revealed in court documents from the Kadrey v. Meta case.
- Plaintiffs, including authors Sarah Silverman and Ta-Nehisi Coates, oppose Meta's claim of ‘fair use’ regarding copyrighted content.
- Internal chats expose discussions around prioritizing speed over legal considerations in acquiring copyrighted materials for AI training, including using platforms like Libgen and the idea of buying e-books at retail prices.

items.title: Brian Armstrong says Coinbase spent $50M fighting SEC lawsuit – and beat it
items.summary:
- Coinbase announced that the SEC has agreed to drop the lawsuit against them with prejudice.
- The lawsuit alleged Coinbase was operating as an unregistered securities exchange.
- CEO Brian Armstrong stated they spent $50 million on legal defenses, citing the need for clearer crypto regulations in the US.
- Armstrong believes the fight was crucial for the future of the crypto industry in America, given that few companies could afford such expenses.

items.title: iOS 18.4 will bring Apple Intelligence-powered ‘Priority Notifications’
items.author: Aisha Malik
items.summary:
- Apple released the developer beta for iOS 18.4 on February 21, 2025, which includes a new feature called "Priority Notifications" powered by Apple Intelligence.
- This feature aims to help users prioritize important notifications and reduce distractions from less important alerts. 
- Important notifications will be shown on the Lock Screen in a separate section, analyzed by Apple Intelligence based on user behavior.
- Users can enable Priority Notifications in the Settings app under the Notifications option.
- Apple Intelligence will also be featured on the Vision Pro with the upcoming visionOS 2.4 in April 2025, along with new features in Apple News+ Food.

items.title: Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang says market got it wrong about DeepSeek’s impact
items.author: Jensen Huang, Alex Bouzari
items.summary:
- Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang criticized market reactions to DeepSeek’s R1 open source reasoning model as misguided.
- He claimed R1 will accelerate AI adoption rather than diminish the need for computing resources.
- Nvidia’s stock dropped 16.9% after the R1 release but has almost fully recovered since then.
- Huang noted that while DeepSeek advanced pre-training AI, post-training remains critical and resource-intensive.
- Nvidia's Q4 earnings report on February 26 is anticipated to address the market’s response to DeepSeek.

items.title: OpenAI Plans to Shift Compute Needs from Microsoft to SoftBank
items.summary:
- OpenAI is looking to shift its main computing power source from Microsoft to SoftBank by 2030.
- The company expects to source 75% of its data center capacity from the Stargate project, backed financially by SoftBank.
- OpenAI's spending on Microsoft data centers will continue to increase in the short term, despite this shift.
- OpenAI forecasts a dramatic increase in overall costs, with projected cash burns reaching $20 billion by 2027, compared to $5 billion in 2024.
